There are 40 days left in 2016. UNHCR reports (http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php) that as of this forecast, about 344,600 refugees have arrived in 2016. If traffic were uniformly distributed across the year, then we should expect a total around 380,000 refugees this year. As it happens, I believe the total number is actually going to be closer to around 360,000. The 650,000 needed to make this true represents a tripling of the highest-traffic month of the crisis (221,000 in October 2015). This probability is vastly closer to 0 than to 1, but nothing is impossible and GJO requires integer forecasts :(

There's strong evidence that the EU's (ham-fisted and ill considered) attempts to reduce the inflow of migrants and refugees is working. During the period of April 1-15, less than 8,000 migrants and refugees have arrived on Europe's shores. That's about half of what we saw last year during this same period[1]. As @Anneinak, @dkc, and @Milosz (as well as others) have pointed out, migrants and refugees are already seeking out other routes - especially Libya-Italy - in place of Turkey-Greece. But it is in no way clear that these alternative routes will support that average of 100,000 migrants and refugees/month for the rest of the year that would be necessary to reach 1,000,000 sea-borne arrivals that is the subject of this question. At the moment, the "human smuggling infrastructure" (I'm sorry, but I can't recall from whom I've borrowed that phrase) does not appear to be in place to move so many people. That might change in the long-run, but I have some doubts about it doing so before 2016 ends. All that said, caution is warranted. Most of the inflow of migrants and refugees to Europe occurs during the last 4 months of the year. So there's a very real possibility of reaching a million, but right now I don't think that possibility can be much more than 2-to-1 against.

The EU TURKEY - deal? The EU reluctantly coming to the table with Turkey to stem the refugee waves seems to have yielded some results after tough negotiations: It now has the right to send the refugees back to Turkey and also has been promised an increase in border security measures by Turkey.In turn, Turkey has been promised 6 billion euros (roughly $6.8 billion) of financial aid for the refugees in the country, visa exemptions for Turks after a set of criteria are fulfilled and the launch of a new chapter to reanimate the EU membership process.
Turkey has until April to comply with 72 different criteria in order to obtain the visa exemption for the European Union.
"There is also a stipulation on establishing an independent commission on monitoring human rights violations by the security forces. There are many criteria. Turkey will be labeled a democratic country if it can implement all of them. Europe for the time being seems to go along with the negotiations, although it knows that these criteria will not be met.”
He added, “The implementation process will be evaluated after the agreement is signed and it will become clear in June 2016 that it will not happen."
Meanwhile, objections are already being heard from Europe. Frans Timmermans, the vice president of the European Commission, said that the visa exemption for Turkey depends on the requirements and that there is no "shortcut" for this. Timmermans, noting that the visa exemption will not be easy to accomplish, also said the requirements must be met by April.
The negotiation of the readmission agreement, which is jointly discussed with Turkey’s visa exemption for the EU, is not a new idea. Turkey, upon signing the agreement, promises to take back the refugees who originated from the east of Turkey and migrated to Europe. However, experts again warn there might be legal disputes with this agreement. Turkey being a signatory of the 1957 Geneva Convention and the added protocol of 1967 does not recognize asylum seekers as refugees. The refugees in the country are only accepted as “guests.” Here we can talk about an extended protection exclusive to the Syrian refugees but no one has full refugee status. This may lead to a debate on Turkey not meeting the directives of the European Parliament on readmission of refugees in a “safe third country.”

Despite huge number of potential migrants it is likely that the EU and individual member states will follow policies of severly restricting influx of illegal migrants and reduce asylum-seekers numbers by various means. Also increasingly migrants will be returned back to the countries they departed from, such agreements are already being made. Potential migrants will receive information that access to Europe is becoming increasingly difficult or impossible. The costs and risks of trying to enter Europe illegally will increase which will also severly curtail numbers who try. It is possible that other countries will become focus of economic migrants. In addition increasing terrorism in Europe means that increasingly Europeans will become hostile to migrants from countries which potentially would support such terrorism. European governments who do not follow such more restrictive policies will most probably be voted out of office at next elections.

The recent deal between the EU and Turkey[a] is probably behind the recent drop in the GJ consensus on this question[b]. But I doubt that's the entire story. There's also been a fall off in the number of migrants and refugees since January[c]. The numbers really tell two difficult-to-reconcile tales. On the one had, the decline from January to February and from February to March suggests that we're riding a function that will get asymptotically close to zero as the summer months approach. If that happens, then - of course - there won't be anything close to 1 million refugees and migrants entering Europe this year. On the other hand, two factors push toward the opposite conclusion. First, the number of refugees and migrants tends to increase sharply as we get closer to the second half of the year because of the better weather. Second, there have already been more than 161,000 refugees and migrants in 2016, 8 times as many as the 22,000 at the end of March in 2015[d].

Current European policy settings are not effective at preventing or deterring migrants from attempting to enter Europe. While there are signs of hardening rhetoric in Germany, whose policies (and whose Chancellor's statements) have served as the biggest magnet, rhetoric alone will not stop people coming. There is a big gap between tough talk and actively closing the doors - and the lure of a better life is stronger than any deterrents on the horizon. It is also worth bearing in mind that migration often has a lag time, with individuals needing to make arrangements, sell their possessions, arrange passage with smugglers and undertake the journey. Moreover, many of those who have successfully made the journey in 2015 will act as anchors and will project confidence to friends and family members in their communities back home, encouraging these people will seek to emulate that journey. So long as the passage from Turkey to Greece and from North Africa to Italy remains effectively open, the numbers attempting the journey are likely to be even higher in 2016 than in 2015. Even in the unlikely event of an effective ceasefire occurring in Syria in 2016 (which I assess at an approximately 10% chance), migrants from a number of other source countries/regions, not least West Africa, are still likely to make the journey, if primarily for (perfectly understandable) economic and lifestyle reasons. The rise of anti-migration and right-wing parties offers some risk to this prediction but not in the short term and only in respect of some countries, not to the point of preventing migration to Europe as a whole.

Some opinions:
1.       To me Europe, the EU and the people are slowly getting sick of this issue and will try to do as much as possible to limit the influx. How, is much disputed, but without action the right-wing populist will win more seats and force action. With the “good times” over, as at least in Germany the life of a typical refugee is not all that prosperous as maybe thought, the economically motived refugees should become less. Why spend 10k€ on travels to get 120€/m pocket money?
2.       Woman and children. Officially 58% were men, but likely it was more, meaning there extended family, once granted asylum are likely to follow. 1 wife and 3-5 kids per man = 2.9 million potential entries…but the key thing is, they will likely be flown in, if they are allowed in. In Germany, it take between 6-24 months to have the status approved, meaning very few families will be transferred in 2016, thus voiding this aspect in light of the GJOpen question
3.       Turkey as a Nato nation, aspiring EU nation and Germany is their main trading partner, pressure to keep there word will be mounting. They most slow down the influx, if only by 50% it still is significant.
4.       Weather, winter has not yet truly hit Europe allowing more than typical /expected entrees in Q4-2015. Should a harsh Q1-2016 winter hit,  it will slow movement and allow governments to prepare for the rest of the year
 
All-in-all:
Maintaining 83k/m is unlikely. Yet, as long as Merkel maintains a “welcome” policy many will be motived. Let us consider that all the 1.7 million in Turkey plus another million from nieghbouring countries will join, plus 0.2 from North Africa. Total: 2.9 million. To channel Gladwell, it seems a tipping point of 'by sea' refugees to Europe has occurred; Syrians being the catalyst of the 2015 crisis, more specifically during 3&4Q 2015. Unfortunately, motivations to flee from the region-at-large will unlikely subside this year. However, I predict Syria's contribution to the 'by sea' numbers will decrease this year. And unless another single country contributes nearly 500,000 refugees in 2016, OR there is a sharp uptick in the sum of multiple not-Syrian refugees, I don't see this 1M threshold being crossed again. Second, I predict at the behest of EU and UN leaders, broader international support will unfold; even small levels of aid from around the world will absorb a significant a portion of the Mediterranean traffic, and I expect these mechanisms will be greased before 3Q (warmer) months. We can hope (I know, that's not a prediction) that West Africa (now Ebola free) will aid in taking in North African IDPs and the same from the GCC states. TBD.
